@graph.description: In 1961, Joe Heitz and his wife, Alice, bought an 8.5-acre vineyard from Leon Brandel named "The One & Only." It was on this property that Joe and Alice founded Heitz Cellars.
name: Joe Heitz founded Heitz Cellar

@graph.description: James Zellerbach hired Brad Webb to be Hanzell's winemaker in 1956. While at Hanzell, Webb pioneered a number of technologies in the cellar, including temperature-controlled stainless steel fermentors, controlled malolactic fermentations, and the use of inert gases. He was among the winemakers who pioneered the use of small French oak barrels for aging wines.
name: Brad Webb was a winemaker at Hanzell Vineyards
winemaker

@graph.description: Goheen developed the index testing techniques and heat treatment therapy for grapevines at the Foundation Plant Materials Service (now Foundation Plant Services). Goheen served as the Scientific Adviser at FPMS from the mid 1950's through 1986.
name: Austin Goheen worked with Foundation Plant Services
worked with

@graph.description: The Martini family's Stanley Ranch was among the vineyards whose Chardonnay plantings were established from the Wente Vineyard, and continued the chain of improvement of the variety by hosting the selection work of Harold Olmo.
name: Louis P. Martini planted Wente Clone
planted

@graph.description: In 1882, Theodore Gier planted the budwood that Wetmore brought from Meursault on Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton.
name: Gier Vineyard planted Meursault Budwood
planted

@graph.description: In 1946, Fred and Eleanor McCrea collected budwood from Wente's Livermore vineyard to plant the Stony Hill vineyard in the Spring Mountain District of Napa Valley. At the time, the decision to plant Chardonnay was controversial, as there were only around 200 documented acres of Chardonnay in California. Stony Hill may have been the first winery to plant a Chardonnay vineyard after Prohibition, and the McCreas did so despite warnings from UC Davis that the variety was unlikely to succeed. UC Davis advised the couple to plant Gewurztraminer, Sémillon and Pinot Blanc to protect against the potential failure of the Chardonnay.
name: Ernest Wente provided budwood to Fred McCrea
provided to

@graph.description: The Martini family's Stanley Ranch was among the vineyards whose Chardonnay plantings were established from the Wente Vineyard, and continued the chain of improvement of the variety by hosting the selection work of Harold Olmo.
name: Stanly Ranch Vineyards planted Wente Clone
planted

@graph.description: Fred and Eleanor McCrea found the property that would become Stony Hill Vineyard in the early 1940s. By 1943, they had made the rugged hillside spot on Spring Mountain their home.
name: Eleanor McCrea co-founded Stony Hill Vineyard
co-founded

At the time, the decision to plant Chardonnay was controversial, as there were only around 200 documented acres of Chardonnay in California. Stony Hill may have been the first winery to plant a Chardonnay vineyard after Prohibition, and the McCreas did so despite warnings from UC Davis that the variety was unlikely to succeed. UC Davis advised the couple to plant Gewurztraminer, Sémillon and Pinot Blanc to protect against the potential failure of the Chardonnay.
name: Wente Vineyards provided budwood to Fred McCrea

@graph.description: In 1942 Louis P. Martini purchased approximately 200 acres of the Stanly Ranch for the Louis M. Martini Winery. In 1948 Louis P. Martini began working with UC Davis and the Wente family on Wente clones of Chardonnay planted in the Stanly Ranch Vineyard.
name: Louis P. Martini owned Stanly Ranch Vineyards
owned

@graph.description: Wente Vineyards did not pull up their Chardonnay vines during Prohibition. After Prohibition, they were one of only a few vineyards with Chardonnay intact.
name: Wente Vineyards survived Prohibition
survived

name: Wente Clone derived from Gier Vineyard

@graph.description: Harold Olmo selected promising material from the Martini planting of the Wente Clone, grown at Martini's Stanley Ranch Vineyard in Carneros, California. Through breeding, and heat treatment to eliminate viral infections, the team was able to raise the average yield from one half ton per acre in the 1950s to over five tons per acre. This improvement made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
name: Harold Olmo developed FPS 04 Clone
developed

Stony Hill may have been the first winery to plant a chardonnay vineyard after Prohibition, and the McCreas did so despite warnings from UC Davis that the variety was unlikely to succeed. @graph.description: In 1882, Charles Wetmore, then the Chief Executive Officer of the California State Board of Viticultural Commissioners, carried Chardonnay budwood from Meursault to Livermore, California, to plant his Cresta Blanca vineyard and distributed the material to local growers.
name: Cresta Blanca Winery planted Meursault Budwood
planted

@graph.description: In 1953, Stony Hill Vineyard provided James D. Zellerbach the Chardonnay budwood that was used to plant Hanzell Vineyards. Because the Wente brothers were widely respected for their efforts to perfect California Chardonnay, Zellerbach sought out the Wente clone when planting his 1953 Ambassador's Vineyard. He continued Wente's practice of evaluating selection, gradually establishing vines perfectly adapted to the growing conditions of Sonoma. Today the vines are known as the Hanzell clone.
name: Stony Hill Vineyard provided budwood to Hanzell Vineyards
provided to

@graph.description: Chardonnay budwood from Meursault found its way from Wetmore's Livermore vineyard to the Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, and from there to the Wente Vineyards, where it was cultivated alongside Chardonnay vines from Montpellier. Through decades of selection, Wente's Chardonnay vines came to be known as the Wente Clone, and adopted by other winemakers seeking to establish plantings of Chardonnay in California.
name: Meursault Budwood became the Wente Clone
became

@graph.description: Harold Olmo selected promising material from the Martini planting of the Wente Clone, grown at Wente's Stanley Ranch Vineyard in Carneros, California. Through breeding, and heat treatment to eliminate viral infections, the team was able to raise the average yield from one half ton per acre in the 1950s to over five tons per acre. This improvement made Chardonnay commercially viable in California.
name: Harold Olmo improved Wente Clone
improved

won

@graph.description: Dr. Harold Olmo was plant breeder on the faculty of the Viticulture and Enology Department at the University of California, Davis, from 1931 until his retirement in 1977. Olmo continued his research in retirement, until shortly before his death.
name: UC Davis Viticulture & Enology Department hired Harold Olmo
hired

@graph.description: Before Prohibition, California's most popular white wines were made from grapes like Green Hungarian, Burger, Sylvaner, Tokay, and Riesling. Chardonnay, now virtually synonymous with California white wine, was grown in such small amounts that it was rarely recorded as a distinct variety.
name: Prohibition reduced pre-Prohibition white wines
reduced

@graph.schema:creator: Los Angeles Times
@graph.creator: https://www.latimes.com/food/la-xpm-2013-mar-15-la-dd-napa-valley-loses-a-pioneer-james-l-barrett-of-chateau-montelena-20130315-story.html
@graph.description:
James (Jim) Barrett was the owner of Chateau Montelena, which won the whites category in the 1976 Judgment of Paris.

 Born in LA in 1926, Barrett served in the navy during World War II. On his return, he graduated from UCLA in 1946 and went on to complete a law degree at Loyola Marymount University.

 When war broke out in Korea he was recalled and served as a lieutenant on a submarine. When the war was over, he built a successful legal practice, but dreamt of starting a winery.

 In 1972, Barrett bought the old stone Château Montelena property in Calistoga, at the time covered in overgrown vineyards and in serious need of attention. He cleared and replanted the original vineyard with Cabernet Sauvignon vines, hired Mike Grgich as winemaker and released his first wines that same year.

 While his Cabernet vines matured, Barrett focused on Chardonnay made from purchased grapes, with the success of the 1973 Chardonnay at the Judgement of Paris tasting turning Château Montelena into a household name.
@graph.name: James (Jim) Barrett
relatedLinkText: Chateau Montelena Owner Jim Barrett Dies at 86
Chateau Montelena Owner Jim Barrett Dies

@graph.creator: https://grapecollective.com/articles/stony-hills-cult-chardonnay-and-napas-longest-tenured-winemaker

@graph.description: Eleanor McCrea was born in Buffalo, NY, in 1907, and moved with her family to California in 1916. She attended private school in Piedmont and then enrolled in university at Wellesley Collection (1925–1929). Following graduation, she worked as a legal secretary until she met and married Fred McCrea. Prior to purchasing Stony Hill, the couple lived in San Francisco.
@graph.name: Eleanor McCrea
relatedLinkText: Stony Hill's Cult Chardonnay and Napa's Longest Tenured Winemaker

@graph.schema:creator: Bella Spurrier/Smithsonian Institution
@graph.description:
Steven Spurrier (born 1941) is a British wine expert and train merchant who has been described as a champion of French wine.

 Spurrier entered the wine trade in 1964 as a trainee with London's oldest wine merchant Christopher and Co. In 1970 he moved to Paris where he persuaded an elderly lady to walk down the Royal Street. From 1971 he ran the wine shop The Caves of the Madeleine where customers were encouraged to taste wines before they bought them, which achieved recognition as a highly regarded specialist wine shop. In 1973 he started The Academy of Wine, France's first private wine school, which featured Michel Bettane and Charles F. Shaw, namesake of "Two Buck Chuck".

 Spurrier went on to stage the influential "Judgment of Paris" Tasting of 1976, when a Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon from California were listed above some of the most prestigious wines of Burgundy and Bordeaux.

 Spurrier sold his wine interests in France and returned to the UK in 1988, becoming a wine consultant and journalist. He is now director of the Christie's Wine Course, which he founded with Christie's Education in 1982. He is also a consultant to Singapore Airlines, and consultant editor at Decanter.
@graph.name: Steven Spurrier
relatedLinkText: Decanter Author Archives for Steven Spurrier

@graph.description: With cuttings from the vine nursery at the University of Montpellier and Chardonnay budwood from the Theodore Gier Vineyard in Pleasanton, which was planted using budwood obtained from Charles Wetmore who brought the budwood from Meursault in Burgundy around 1882, Ernest Wente began the 30- to 40-year process of selecting only vines with favorable traits and replanting them. Over time this Chardonnay became known as the Wente clone (actually several clones) and was planted in many vineyards in California and beyond.
name: Wente Vineyards cultivated Wente Clone
cultivated

@graph.description: It was Patricia Gallagher's idea to organize the 1976 Judgment of Paris in honor of the American Bicentennial. She was the one who suggested the idea to Steven Spurrier.
name: Patricia Gallagher organized the 1976 Judgment of Paris
organized

@graph.creator: https://americanhistory.si.edu/blog/40th-anniversary-paris-tasting
@graph.schema:creator: National Museum of American History
@graph.description:
Patricia Gastaud-Gallagher was a director at the Académie du Vin in Paris. She came up with the idea for, co-hosted, and participated in the Judgment of Paris wine tasting event. She was also on the Copia panel that oversaw the rematch on The Judgment of Paris 30th Anniversary. 

 After her time at Académie du Vin, Gastaud-Gallagher went on to write influential wine columns in French publications, earned a degree as an enology technician, and was the editorial director of the International Who’s Who in Wine & Spirits. She then became the academic director and director of the wine department of the famous Le Cordon Bleu school of cuisine and pastry. She is a co-author of the book Le Cordon Bleu Wine Essentials: Professional Secrets to Buying, Storing, Serving, and Drinking Wine.

 Originally from Delaware, she is one of the few non-French natives to have won the distinguished Chevalier du Mérite Agricole given for distinguished service to the French Wine industry (1994).
@graph.name: Patricia Gastaud-Gallagher
relatedLinkText: Potable Quotables on the 40th Anniversary of the Paris Tasting
The Hidden Figures Behind the Judgment of Paris

@graph.description: Chardonnay became one of the first cultivars on which the utility of heat treatment against viruses, or thermotherapy, was demonstrated. In 1964, Harold Olmo took selections of the Wente Clone from the Martini Vineyards to the Foundation Plant Services for heat treatment to remove viruses that were impeding yields. Clones from this improvement program eventually became the most widely planted Chardonnay selections in California.
name: Austin Goheen improved the FPS 04 Clone
improved
